properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall possible over parts of northeastern Ontario tonight through Tuesday night. Rain is expected to begin today over areas to the east of Lake Superior and spread to the east and northeast tonight. General rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are likely in a swath from north of Sault Ste. Marie to Timmins. Localized higher amounts could reach 60 mm by Wednesday morning. This rainfall is associated with a slow moving low pressure system approaching from the US Midwest. Environment Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when 50 mm in 24 hours is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T01:20:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T09:21:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2446830058.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake, Gogama - Foleyet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 14 degrees Celsius will end tonight. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-22T12:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T02:27:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3335198461.2020
Area: North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko, Hay River Region including Enterprise, Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Smoke is expected or occurring. High levels of air pollution are expected today due to smoke from forest fires. The smoke plumes from forest fires in the Chute-des-Passes area may affect neighbouring regions. Air quality could deteriorate should the smoke go down to ground level. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If your home is not air-conditioned, be sure the house doesn't get too warm when doors and windows are closed to keep out smoke. Exposure to too much heat can also result in illness. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-23T00:56:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T08:57:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0389882935.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will continue streaming into the regions from the south. Heat warning criteria is expected to be reached again today. Cloud cover will reduce maximum temperatures below warning criteria Tuesday however it is expected to remain humid. Significantly cooler temperatures will arrive Tuesday night. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T00:45:41-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 39 are expected for the next 2 days. The heat wave will continue into the week. Time span: today and Tuesday. Maximum temperatures today 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39). Minimum Temperatures tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperatures on Tuesday 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39). Locations: New Brunswick except along the Fundy Coast. Remarks: Hot and humid conditions will continue today and Tuesday for most of New Brunswick. Some areas may exceed warning criteria again on Tuesday night and Wednesday before a break in the heat. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms continue to develop along a surface trough this afternoon and will continue into the evening. Some of these thunderstorms may become severe. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-22T09:54:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T01:08:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3848638748.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Another heat wave for the Annapolis Valley will begin today. Time span: today and Tuesday. Maximum temperature today: 28 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36). Minimum temperatures tonight: 18 Celsius. Maximum Temperature Tuesday: 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36). Locations: Annapolis Valley. Remarks: Another run of very warm days will begin today. Temperatures over the next few days will be near 29 degrees with humidex values near 36. A break in the heat may be possible on Thursday or Friday. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-22T23:53:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T07:54:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1298024062.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County
